titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Thomas E. Cox papers, 1835-1853
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Rubenstein Staff; EAD finding aid derived from MARC record using marc2ead_sectionA.xsl

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid derived from MARC record via marc2ead_sectionA.xsl, September 2018

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.abstract: Personal letters written by and to Thomas E. Cox, a student at the College of William and Mary, Williamsburg, Virginia, 1835-1836, and later a physician in Richmond. One letter from an acquaintance vigorously argues that the facilities for medical education in the South are equal to those in the North.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.p: Thomas E. Cox Papers, 1835-1853, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: Student at the College of William and Mary and later physician of Richmond, Virginia

processinfo.p: This finding aid was derived from a MARC record using a crosswalk defined in marc2ead_sectionA.xsl. The finding aid was generated as part of a larger project to digitize several thousand small collections housed in Section A, September 2018.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Personal letters written by and to Thomas E. Cox, a student at the College of William and Mary, Williamsburg, Virginia, 1835-1836, and later a physician in Richmond. One letter from an acquaintance vigorously argues that the facilities for medical education in the South are equal to those in the North.

controlaccess.subject: Medical education -- Southern States -- 19th century
